title: Jean Boissel
text:
Jean Anselme Boissel (1 May 1891 – 19 October 1951) was a French architect, journalist, and <a href="far%20right">far right</a> political activist who was convicted of <a href="Collaboration%20with%20the%20Axis%20Powers%20during%20World%20War%20II%23France">collaboration with Nazi Germany</a>.
A disabled veteran of World War I, Boissel founded <a href="Le%20Front%20Franc">Le Front Franc</a>— and the Paris-based periodical, "<a href="Le%20R%C3%A9veil%20du%20peuple">Le Réveil du peuple</a>" (["Revival of the People"])— which espoused <a href="Anti-Masonry">anti-Masonic</a>, <a href="anti-parliamentarianism">anti-parliamentarian</a>, and "<a href="antisemitic">antijudéo</a><a href="m%C3%A9t%C3%A8que">métèque</a>" views. Originally sentenced to death after the war, Boissel died in prison.
Life.
Jean Anselme Boissel was born in <a href="Bains%2C%20Haute-Loire">Bains</a>. His father was a policeman.
Boissel fought in World War I; he was severely injured and received the <a href="Croix%20de%20Guerre">Croix de Guerre</a>. He was the architect of many buildings, mainly <a href="villa">villa</a>s in <a href="Le%20Touquet-Paris-Plage">Le Touquet-Paris-Plage</a>, some of which are classified in the general inventory of French architectural heritage.
Politics.
Boissel came to be heavily influenced by the ethno-racialist concepts of <a href="Arthur%20de%20Gobineau">Arthur de Gobineau</a>. He became active in political journalism and, in 1933, he published a book titled "Les Croix le sang" (["The Cross of Blood"]). In 1934, he undertook the founding of a <a href="far-right%20league">far-right league</a> called Racisme International Fascism, later renamed <a href="Le%20Front%20Franc">Le Front Franc</a>. Starting in March 1936, Boissel founded the Paris-based periodical "", which he edited as an organ of the Front. 
Boissel established contacts with the leaders of the German <a href="Nazi%20Party">Nazi Party</a>. In May 1935, he went to <a href="Nuremberg">Nuremberg</a> to participate in the congress of the <a href="Universal%20Anti-Jewish%20League">Universal Anti-Jewish League</a> ("<a href="La%20Ligue%20Antijuive%20Universelle">La Ligue Antijuive Universelle</a>") alongside <a href="Julius%20Streicher">Julius Streicher</a>.
Boissel was received by Adolf Hitler in 1936.
He corresponded with <a href="Theodor%20Kessemeier">Theodor Kessemeier</a>, head of the <a href="Deutscher%20Fichte-Bund">Deutscher Fichte-Bund</a>.
Boissel was sentenced to four months in prison in 1938 for uttering <a href="death%20threat">death threat</a>s against <a href="L%C3%A9on%20Blum">Léon Blum</a> —then <a href="List%20of%20Prime%20Ministers%20of%20France%23Presidents%20of%20the%20Council%20of%20Ministers%203">President of the Council</a>—in "Le Réveil du peuple". The following year he defended <a href="Roger%20Cazy">Roger Cazy</a>, regional delegate of the Front Franc, who was jailed for spreading Nazi propaganda in <a href="Arras">Arras</a>.
In October 1939, he was arrested on suspicion of collaboration with the Germans and imprisoned by <a href="%C3%89douard%20Daladier">Édouard Daladier</a>. After the <a href="occupation%20of%20France">occupation of France</a> by German troops, he was released on 10 July 1940.
In mid-1941, he became a member of the Central Committee of the <a href="Legion%20of%20French%20Volunteers%20against%20Bolshevism">Legion of French Volunteers against Bolshevism</a> and lead its recruitment campaign.
In contrast to <a href="Marcel%20D%C3%A9at">Marcel Déat</a>, <a href="Jacques%20Doriot">Jacques Doriot</a>, or <a href="Eug%C3%A8ne%20Deloncle">Eugène Deloncle</a>, Boissel took a secondary role in the collaboration. He chaired a <a href="collaborationist">collaborationist</a> splinter <a href="groupuscule">groupuscule</a>, <a href="l%27Union%20des%20forces%20fran%C3%A7aises">l'Union des forces françaises</a> (the Union of French Forces), which organized a "<a href="pilgrimage">pilgrimage</a>" to the grave of <a href="anti-Semitic">anti-Semitic</a> polemicist <a href="%C3%89douard%20Drumont">Édouard Drumont</a> in February 1943.
Under the occupation, Boissel resumed leadership of the Front, and revived "Le Réveil du peuple" in 1943 (its last issue was on 16 August 1944).
After the <a href="liberation%20of%20France">liberation of France</a> by Allied troops in 1944, he was arrested for collaboration with the Nazis and sentenced to death on 28 June 1946. His property was confiscated and he was removed from the <a href="Legion%20of%20Honour">Legion of Honour</a>. His sentence was commuted on December 2. He died in prison on 19 October 1951.
Architectural achievements.
Poste du Touquet.
Boissel designed the , which functions as a <a href="La%20Poste%20%28France%29">post office</a> in <a href="Le%20Touquet">Le Touquet</a> (photos and ).
Boissel won a competition organized by the municipality (beating out the architects <a href="Louis%20Quetelart">Louis Quetelart</a> and ). Boissel wanted to preserve the memory that it was built on the site of the former <a href="Church%20of%20Saint-Jean">Church of Saint-Jean</a>, with the inclusion of a small <a href="bell%20tower">bell tower</a>. It was built in 1927 by the <a href="Delcourt%20Brothers">Delcourt Brothers</a>. Contributors to the project included the <a href="ceramist">ceramist</a> <a href="Delassus">Delassus</a>, and the <a href="glass%20painter">glass painter</a> <a href="Jeannin%20Ga%C3%ABtan">Jeannin Gaëtan</a>.
It was designated a <a href="Monument%20historique">historical monument</a> on 12 May 1997.
In popular culture.
In <a href="Louis-Ferdinand%20C%C3%A9line">Louis-Ferdinand Céline</a>'s 1957 novel "<a href="Castle%20to%20Castle">Castle to Castle</a>", the character Neuneuil is thought to be based on Boissel.
